Comment: It’s not. This is a public-private partnership. The investment the government makes is minimal, but provides funding across all stations which helps make the cost of broadcast technology, programming rights, and music rights attainable whether your station has the individual funding to buy it or not. That’s why this potential cut is disproportionate and will cause rural stations to go off the air. Many of them receive 40% or more of their annual operation revenue from the government. stations in larger cities need less. All can then focus on diverse streams of revenue from individuals and sponsors. When you take away the government portion (which is $1.60 per person in our country per year - less than a cup of coffee in taxes), that has the potential to collapse the system.   These stations also serve as local outlets for the country’s emergency warning systems. They educate children in areas where pre-k is limited or doesn’t exist. And it’s FREE to all Americans to use, for a low investment.

Comment: You’re right. It’s not free because it is subsidized by taxes, which means there is no fee to users at the point of access. It is publicly funded by tax dollars, at a very, very minimal cost. Your public library works the same way. There is no fee to you to have a library card. You could choose to buy the book, just like you could choose to pay for a Netflix subscription. However, this creates inequities to access for people who do not have the money to pay for these services. That’s why having a public media option that is not controlled by corporate interests, is important in a democracy.
